newsitem.title: TAIWAN: Taiwan Metals - Market conditions - April 1.
newsitem.headline: Taiwan Metals - Market conditions - April 1.

text.p: Taiwan's aluminium ingots prices fell to T$49.00 per kg from T$51.00 two weeks ago, reflecting a recent decline in aluminium prices on the London Metal Exchange, traders said on Tuesday.

Taiwan aluminium demand appeared to be increasing as the island's leading aluminium plate maker, China Steel Aluminium Co, a subsidiary of China Steel Corp, reported its March production at over 7,000 tonnes -- a company record high.
Company officials attributed the volume increase to strong demand for aluminium plate from Taiwan's booming electronics industry, a major export sector.
"Our production volume reached a record high in March," a company official said.
Taiwan imported some 480,000 tonnes of gross aluminium in 1995, up from 450,000 tonnes in 1994. Figures for 1996 were not yet available.
Other basic metals remained unchanged during the latter half of March, but demand could pick up slowly as the government's many economy stimulus plans take effect.

The interior ministry announced on March 27 it was arranging T$61.477 billion in government credits to offer supplementary low-cost loans for first-time homebuyers in a bid to boost the sluggish property market.
Construction remains Taiwan's top sector for basic metals consumption.
Construction shares in Taiwan's stock market rose on Tuesday on preliminary reports of good March sales in the beleaguered property market and investor hopes for better sales in April.

Brokers said construction firms had launched aggressive ad campaigns promoting planned residential buildings worth some T$200 billion, hoping to lure homebuyers into their sales rooms during the March 29-30 and April 4-6 holidays.
Analysts cautioned that the spring promotions take place every year and that it was too soon to know whether a significant housing rebound was taking hold.
